The only issue I've had with using Flash CS5 to directly deploy to iOS and Android via AIR is screen size issues. I usually have to start a new document for different screen sizes.

@yosunchang Adapting to variable screen sizes is a challenge for any mobile development project. With smaller screens, it's sometimes necessary to develop new solutions or ways for the user to interact (for example, in my latest mobile project I actually coded an entire suite of UI components based on Adobe's CS3 UI components (list, combo box, color picker, etc.).  Depending on the complexity of your application, you can also design fluid interfaces that adapt automatically to variable screen resolution and DPI. Here's a great article that explains how to do so: http://www.adobe.com/devnet/flash/articles/authoring_for_multiple_screen_sizes.html

The beauty of CS5 is that you have one coding language and one suite capable of handling all your needs vs. having to recode your entire game's source code over again. I'd love to chat more with you and others at FGS interested in learning and sharing more about mobile game development using Flash.
